title: Get API keys
text: context literature review, needs low request rate quota, need key use PubMed API. info : https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/tools/developers/

title: Get API keys
text: Access Elsevier developer portal : https://dev.elsevier.com/ Click “want API key” Sign institutional/organisation credentials Click “Create API key” Enter label API key (avoid use spaces name) don’t need provide website URL Read API Service Agreement Tick “agree API Service Agreement” Read text data mining provisions Tick “agree TDM Provisions” Click “Submit” redirected “API Key” find API key

title: Get API keys
text: Access Clarivate developer portal : https://developer.clarivate.com/ Click log already member, sign using institutional/organisation credentials Click “Applications” top page Enter application ID (avoid use spaces name) Enter application name Enter application description explain use API (e.g., running systematic review dog vaccine) Choose client type “Confidential: Server side application, can keep secrets confidential tick “application use OAuth2.0 Flows (Client Credentials flow, .e. using redirects)” Click “Register application” Click “APIs” top page Select tile “Web Science API Expanded” bottom page click “Subscribe” need wait Clarivate approve application provide individual API key (can take several days weeks, hesitate contact Clarivate support team updates ts.support.anz@clarivate.com) Well done! Now got API keys, can continue next tutorial → LitFetchR (Tutorial)

title: LitFetchR (Tutorial)
text: strongly recommend create new R directory individual review project. RStudio: Go File>New Project…>New Directory>New Project Choose name directory (e.g. review_fish_vibrio), Browse... choose save directory. suggest save directory computer (e.g. C:/users/...) instead clouds (e.g. OneDrive, Box, etc.), restriction access institution might block R. Click Create Project new directory, install LitFetchR GitHub: load package:
code: #This step can be skipped if `LitFetchR` is already installed  #Install using devtools package install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("thomasdumond/LitFetchR")  #or  #Install using remotes package install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("thomasdumond/LitFetchR") #Load LitFetchR library(LitFetchR)

title: LitFetchR (Tutorial)
text: Save API keys personal R environment: allow LitFetchR locally access personal API keys keeping confidential need share code collaborators. mentionned R, important restart session continuing: Session>Restart R load LitFetchR using library(LitFetchR) don’t API keys Scopus Web Science, see Get API keys.
code: #This step can be skipped if your API keys have already been saved. Repeat this step if your API keys changed.  #Load LitFetchR library(LitFetchR)  #Save API keys in your R environment save_api_keys(WOS_API_KEY = "your-wos-api-key", SCP_API_KEY = "your-scp-api-key")  #Example of what you should see: #> save_api_keys(WOS_API_KEY = "abcd01234", SCP_API_KEY = "efgh5678") #Saved key(s) WOS_API_KEY, SCP_API_KEY to -path-to-your-renvironment/.Renviron. #Restart R for the new environment variable(s) to be available.

title: LitFetchR (Tutorial)
text: interactive create_save_search() function guide workflow. example see: using create_save_search(), two new files appear directory: search_list.txt file contains name search string saved using create_save_search(). essential file retrieve reference later. modify search string file, modified search string used future reference retrieval. history_search.xlsx file contains search run using function create_save_search(). time run function, creates new sheet named current date saves search string sent literature platforms, number results returned. already validated review search string, use create_save_search() save search string setup file required continue toward automation reference retrieval.
code: #Load LitFetchR library(LitFetchR)  #The following function can help to create your search string(s) #It has to be used to save your search string(s) create_save_search()  # Example of what you should see building the search: fish AND "vibrio harveyi" AND diagnostic # # > create_save_search() # History had been created. # Enter your search string (or 'summary' or 'exit'): fish # [1] "fish" # [1] "Web of Science: 1793296 results" # [1] "Scopus: 718644 results" # [1] "PubMed: 384742 results" # Enter your search string (or 'summary' or 'exit'): fish AND "vibrio harveyi" # [1] "fish AND \"vibrio harveyi\"" # [1] "Web of Science: 2084 results" # [1] "Scopus: 1080 results" # [1] "PubMed: 727 results" # Enter your search string (or 'summary' or 'exit'): fish AND "vibrio harveyi" AND diagnostic # [1] "fish AND \"vibrio harveyi\" AND diagnostic" # [1] "Web of Science: 126 results" # [1] "Scopus: 22 results" # [1] "PubMed: 106 results" # Enter your search string (or 'summary' or 'exit'): summary #                                Search_Term Results_WOS Results_SCP Results_PMD # 1                                     fish     1793296      718644      384742 # 2                fish AND "vibrio harveyi"        2084        1080         727 # 3 fish AND "vibrio harveyi" AND diagnostic         126          22         106 # Select the index number for the search string to use in automated retrieval: 3 #  # Selected search string: fish AND "vibrio harveyi" AND diagnostic  # Do you want to save the search string for future use? (yes/no): yes # Enter a name for the search identification: fish_vibrio # Search string saved successfully. # Enter your search string (or 'summary' or 'exit'): exit # Exiting search tool.

title: LitFetchR (Tutorial)
text: automated reference retrieval uses either Windows Task Scheduler Cron (Mac/Linux). specify , LitFetchR detect system setup task using following: running auto_LitFetchR_setup() first time, four new files created: history_id.xlsx file contains databases unique identifiers (e.g. PMID SCOPUS_ID). saved used reference retrieval extract references retrieved . history_dedup_YYYY_MM_HHMMSS.xlsx file contains history steps deduplication, using package ASySD. citationsCSV_YYYY_MM_HHMMSS.CSV file contains unique list references retrieved search conducted date referenced name file. CSV file, ready imported screening tool choice reference manager. auto_LitFetchR_code(READ_ONLY).R file contains code automatically run scheduled task (uses function manual_fetch()). set “READ ” avoid accidental modification impair scheduled task action. deleted file accident, use auto_LitFetchR_setup() create new task new code file. time auto_LitFetchR_code(READ_ONLY).R runs, new unique history_dedup_ citationCSV_ files created history_id updated. Congratulations ! automated reference retrieval ready work !
code: #Load LitFetchR library(LitFetchR)  #We recommend using a single word for the *task_ID* or to use underscores "_" to separate words. #The retrieval frequency is currently available "DAILY", "WEEKLY" or "MONTHLY". #You need to use a 24H format for the time of reference retrieval. #If you do not have an API key for WOS and/or SCP or want to exclude any database, #change "TRUE" to "FALSE" in front of the corresponding database (e.g.`WOS = FALSE`).  auto_LitFetchR_setup(task_ID = "name_of_your_task",                      when = "DAILY",                      time = "09:00",                      WOS = TRUE,                      SCP = TRUE,                      PMD = TRUE)  #Example of what you should see #> auto_LitFetchR_setup(task_ID = "fish_vibrio",                      # when = "WEEKLY",                      # time = "14:00",                      # WOS = TRUE,                      # SCP = TRUE,                      # PMD = TRUE) #Task scheduled!

title: Manual reference retrieval
text: individual review R directory, load LitFetchR:

title: Manual reference retrieval
text: Make sure save search string using create_save_search() following function need access file search_list.txt, see LitFetchR (Tutorial). running manual_fetch(), new unique history_dedup_ citationCSV_ files created history_id updated.See bottom page LitFetchR (Tutorial)
code: #Load LitFetchR library(LitFetchR)  #Retrieve the list of references corresponding to your saved search string(s) manual_fetch(WOS = TRUE, SCP = TRUE, PMD = TRUE)  #Example of what you should see:  # > manual_fetch(WOS = TRUE, SCP = TRUE, PMD = TRUE) # [1] 126 # Finished batch number 1 # Finished batch number 2 # [1] "10.1016/j.aaf.2023.11.002 1 / 126" # [1] "10.3390/fishes10090439 2 / 126" # [FOR THE PURPOSE OF THIS EXAMPLE WE DO ARE NOT SHOWING EACH LINE OF THE COMMAND] # [1] "NA 125 / 126" # [1] "NA 126 / 126" # [1] 22 # Finished batch number 1 # File already exists # [1] "10.1007/s12602-023-10207-x 1 / 22" # [1] "10.1016/j.fsi.2025.110189 2 / 22" # [FOR THE PURPOSE OF THIS EXAMPLE WE DO ARE NOT SHOWING EACH LINE OF THE COMMAND] # [1] "10.1111/j.1472-765X.2010.02894.x 21 / 22" # [1] "NA 22 / 22" # [1] 106 # Finished batch 1 for fish AND "vibrio harveyi" AND diagnostic # File already exists # [1] "10.1016/j.fsi.2025.110503 1 / 106" # [1] "10.1016/j.fsi.2025.110501 2 / 106" # [FOR THE PURPOSE OF THIS EXAMPLE WE DO ARE NOT SHOWING EACH LINE OF THE COMMAND][1] "NA 105 / 106" # [1] "NA 106 / 106" # Warning: The following columns are missing: pages, number, record_id, isbn # formatting data... # identifying potential duplicates... # identified duplicates! # flagging potential pairs for manual dedup... # Joining with `by = join_by(duplicate_id.x, duplicate_id.y)` # 254 citations loaded... # 14 duplicate citations removed... # 240 unique citations remaining! # Deduplication script has been executed, concatenated deduplicated references had been exported. # Warning message: # In add_missing_cols(raw_citations) : #   Search contains missing values for the record_id column. A record_id will be created using row numbers

title: Remove or change a scheduled task
text: individual review R directory, load LitFetchR:

title: Remove or change a scheduled task
text: Just use following function name scheduled task:
code: #Load LitFetchR library(LitFetchR)  #remove a scheduled task using its name/identification remove_scheduled_task("taskID")  #Example of what you should see: # > remove_scheduled_task("fish_vibrio") # SUCCESS: The scheduled task "fish_vibrio" was successfully deleted. # Windows task 'fish_vibrio' removed (or did not exist).

title: Remove or change a scheduled task
text: function directly modify scheduled task moment. can simply: Remove scheduled task (see ) Setup new task → see LitFetchR (Tutorial)

what: Automatically Fetching References Metadata from Literature Databases
title: Automatically Fetching References Metadata from Literature Databases
text: purpose LitFetchR automatically retrieve deduplicate references based saved search string(s). Access Web Science Scopus requires personal API keys, PubMed can queried without one.

title: Automatically Fetching References Metadata from Literature Databases
text: can install development version LitFetchR GitHub using devtools remotes:
code: #install via devtools install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("thomasdumond/LitFetchR")  #install via remotes install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("thomasdumond/LitFetchR")

title: Automatically Fetching References Metadata from Literature Databases
text: can find tutorial Articles tab.

title: Automatically Fetching References Metadata from Literature Databases
text: package uses API access Web Science Scopus platforms. enjoy full performance LitFetchR, request personal API keys platforms. information API keys, can see tutorial Get API keys. affiliated university suggest contacting local librarian discuss use API keys (.e. quota access, detail databases accessed Web Science). PubMed require API key access, package can still used access PubMed . scientific platforms databases considered inclusion future versions package.

what: Automating the retrieval of references based on a saved search string — auto_LitFetchR_setup
title: Automating the retrieval of references based on a saved search string — auto_LitFetchR_setup
text: auto_LitFetchR_setup creates read-Rscript task run code automatically specified frequency time, three platforms (e.g. Web Science, Scopus PubMed)

title: Automating the retrieval of references based on a saved search string — auto_LitFetchR_setup
code: auto_LitFetchR_setup(   task_ID = "task_ID",   when = "DAILY",   time = "08:00",   WOS = TRUE,   SCP = TRUE,   PMD = TRUE,   dedup = FALSE,   open_file = FALSE )

title: Automating the retrieval of references based on a saved search string — auto_LitFetchR_setup
text: task_ID Name automated task (e.g. one keyword describing review) Frequency fetching, .e. DAILY, WEEKLY, MONTHLY time Time fetching, .e. HH:MM 24-hour clock format WOS Choose search Web Science (TRUE FALSE) SCP Choose search Scopus (TRUE FALSE) PMD Choose search PubMed (TRUE FALSE) dedup Choose deduplicate references (TRUE FALSE) open_file choose automatically open CSV file reference retrieval

title: Automating the retrieval of references based on a saved search string — auto_LitFetchR_setup
text: Create Rscript file (READ ) task Task Scheduler (Windows), Cron (Mac/Linux)

title: Automating the retrieval of references based on a saved search string — auto_LitFetchR_setup
code: # \donttest{  # Example of what you should see:  auto_LitFetchR_setup(task_ID = "fish_vibrio",                        when = "WEEKLY",                        time = "14:00",                        WOS = TRUE,                        SCP = TRUE,                        PMD = TRUE) #> At your own risk: will set the cron schedule as is: 'weekly' #> Are you sure you want to add the specified cron job: '/opt/R/4.5.2/lib/R/bin/Rscript '/home/runner/work/LitFetchR/LitFetchR/docs/reference/auto_LitFetchR_code(READ_ONLY).R'  >> '/home/runner/work/LitFetchR/LitFetchR/docs/reference/auto_LitFetchR_code(READ_ONLY).log' 2>&1'? [y/n]:  #> Error in if (!input %in% "y") {    message("No action taken.")    return(invisible())}: argument is of length zero #> Task scheduled! # }
